text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
SABAH
- Two arrested militants from a leftist guerrilla group say they were trained in Syria for two years.

- An extra 100,000 tonnes of tobacco is expected this harvest after former prime minister Necmettin Erbakan lifted a quota imposed on tobacco planting. State-owned tobacco and drink producer Teke, will buy the extra tobacco for $400 million and burn it.
MILLIYET
- The new government vows to implement military-inspired education reforms that would hurt Islamic schools.
- Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz declared Turkey's budget deficit as 720 trillion Turkish lira for the first half of 1997.
HURRIYET
- Bulent Orakoglu, a key man in a scandal over spying on the army, returned to Turkey from the United States.
YENI YUZYIL
- Former interior minister Meral Aksener has cancelled a news conference on the spy scandal.
RADIKAL
- The new government cancels tenders worth trillions of lira that were opened by former Islamist government.
CUMHURIYET
- A state security court refuses to handle the case of allegations that the former deputy prime minister Tansu Ciller is a CIA spy and says it should be dealt with by a military court.
DUNYA
- The new government's priority will be to reduce inflation.
- The industrial output of Turkey soars. April and May outputs are higher when compared to figures of the months in 1996.
ZAMAN
- Leading Islamist deputy Oguzhan Asilturk criticise new government programme.
